description:
Diorhabda carinulata is a species of leaf beetle native to Central Asia. It is a small insect, typically measuring between 5-8 millimeters in length.

The species is characterized by its elongated, oval-shaped body and a distinctive dorsal carinula (a raised ridge) running along the center of its pronotum (the segment behind the head). The elytra (hardened forewings) are usually light brown or yellowish in color, sometimes with darker spots or patterns.

Diorhabda carinulata is known to feed primarily on plants in the Tamarix genus, also known as saltcedars, which are invasive shrubs or small trees introduced to North America. The beetle's feeding on these plants has made it a biological control agent used to manage the spread of Tamarix in areas where it has become a problematic invasive species.

The life cycle of D. carinulata involves egg, larval, pupal, and adult stages. The larvae and adults both feed on the foliage of Tamarix plants, contributing to the beetle's effectiveness as a biocontrol agent.

Overall, Diorhabda carinulata is an ecologically important insect due to its role in controlling the invasive Tamarix species in certain regions where it has been introduced as a biological control measure.
